Intel Core i7-13650HX
NVIDIA GeForce RTX 4060 8GB
RAM DDR5 24GB

Helldivers 2 is, at its core, a fantastic game. The moment-to-moment gameplay is thrilling, the cooperative mechanics are tight, and the presentation captures the spirit of chaotic camaraderie better than most. But despite this strong foundation, it’s hard to ignore that the game is being held back by a lack of long-term, meaningful content — and a concerning trend of scaled-back offerings in recent warbonds.

The cadence of updates is sluggish. Months pass between meaningful additions, and when they do arrive, they often lack the depth or staying power to keep the player base engaged for long. A few new weapons or cosmetics aren’t enough to sustain interest when deeper progression systems remain underdeveloped.

What Helldivers 2 desperately needs is a shift in focus toward lasting progression and enhanced player agency. A perfect opportunity for this lies in the long-teased attachment system. By fully realizing this feature — and offering a broad selection of attachments that can be freely applied across weapon types — the game could open the door to creative, personalized builds. Let players experiment. Let them make wild, even ridiculous loadouts and find what works best for their squad.

Even better, tie these attachments into the existing resource economy. Give players a reason to keep grinding samples and requisition slips — not for more throwaway gear, but for unlocks that meaningfully expand their tactical options. This kind of system would echo the rewarding progression loop from the first game, giving players real goals to chase and builds to refine.

Helldivers 2 has all the potential in the world. With deeper systems and more consistent content delivery, it could go from great to legendary. Right now, though, it risks burning out its most loyal players before it gets there.

Though in my opinion not as charming as the original Helldivers, Helldivers 2 brings the chaotic co-op action into 3D. retaining the silly deaths and big booms while introducing all new items in the form of weapons, stratagems, and enemies. Weapons feel satisfying to use, stratagems feel insanely powerful, and enemies are a pleasure to cut through with democratic ease.  The paid currency can be found in-game, meaning everything can be earned for free (and honestly the grind isn't all that bad).  The progression feels satisfying and unlocking a new item always gets me excited to try it out.  The voice acting is great.
The game is quite resource-intensive on my computer, but that's to be expected.  It occasionally loses frames for about a minute but then returns to normal gameplay for the rest of the mission.
Enemy variety is awesome except for the Illuminate (still holding out hope that we'll see the original Illuminate return).  Bugs are satisfying to squish and burn and present a decent "beginner" faction to ease people into the game.  Bots provide a satisfying challenge (even if their aim sucks often) which feels like an actual fight should shit hit the fan, as it often does in Helldivers.  Illuminate are boring in my opinion, but hopefully they'll get fleshed out eventually with their old units.
Teamwork is much less present in this game as compared to the previous (which forced teamwork by locking everyone to the same screen, resulting in many hilarious shenanigans).  Oftentimes everyone will run off on their own and clear the map, only ever asking for help for a certain point of interest that requires two players.  When you DO get a team that is willing to work together, though, oh boy...  It feels AWESOME.  Ripping and tearing through enemies, blowing stuff up with a democratic lack of prejudice, accidentally shooting your teammate with a machine gun because they dove into your line of fire.
It's an amazing game.  It could improve, but it is still very fun.

As a massive fan of the original game, I do not like the sequel. It feels like less of a co-op game and more of a "everyone split up and do their own thing" kind of game because the game is designed in ways that punish you for wanting to stay together with your teammates so it just feels heavily discouraged. Enemy spawns struggle to split between 4 players in different parts of the map so it results in the hardest difficulty feeling hilariously easy at times when one or more people barely get any spawns and just freely do objectives, but if you stay together you all get all the enemies spawns pretty much all the time which just ends up wasting so much time.

Helldivers 1 was built, designed, and balanced a lot around co-op centric things, your team had far more reason to have different roles and loadouts instead of making a strong versatile build that can do everything independently, team reload mechanic was a much stronger and encouraged mechanic, and the team was not allowed to be separated.

A lot of strategems and weapons also just feel worse than the HD1 counterparts in terms of damage, ammo economy, and general effectiveness. The standard Breaker shotgun and the Kinetic Shield are some of the worst offenders to me.

HD2 also lacks some crucial teamwork focused strategems that people like me desperately want back, such as the Rep-80 heal beam gun, or the Angel Guard dog medical backpack. The stim pistol was not a fun addition to the game as trying to hit people with that is insufferable, I don't care if people say it's skill issue, it is not fun, and not like it's very effective anyway cause players tend to die faster than it can heal anyway.

Player survivability in HD2 also just does not feel as fair or as fun as HD1 too. The incap system was completely removed so you just outright die (Gives another less incentive to use SMG's compared to HD1, hell you can't even carry artillery shells with one hand and shoot a one handed weapon at the same time anymore either), and weak enemies can even kill you in just a mere few hits sometimes. The games survivability relying so much on stims is not particularly a design choice I like either. I wish they kept the incap system and players being a bit tankier, and you had very very slow health regen instead if you arn't taking damage. (Stims should of been something in the grenade slot instead to replace grenades in my opinion.)

I don't like how armor went from a cosmetic only thing in HD1 so you could wear what you want and select the perk you wanted separately, to now armor passives have to be handcuffed to armors that I don't want to wear while the ones I want to wear have awful passives or ones I really don't want to use cause it won't complement my build. Which is rather annoying.

Performance and game stability is also not particularly great either. This game used to run well on my system early on but after a bunch of updates it feels like it really struggles to be stable, I know they started trying to address this though it's still not anywhere near how well the game used to run yet. (I acknowledge more major engine tech stuff may take time, but felt I'd mention this.)

I donno, maybe it's a hot take, but I do not like this game because it took away the biggest thing I praised the original for and that's feeling like a true co-op designed experience first and foremost, where lone wolf gameplay was actively discouraged. I don't like some of the other design decisions/changes too. I'd only recommend this game if you are okay with it being nothing like the original game, the game itself isn't terrible, but as an original fan it feels too alienating for me, like it was catoring to a completely different audience for the sake of being mainstream. 

There's a lot more I'm probably forgetting off the top of my head right now, so I'll end it with this. TLDR: I wish this game just tried to be more like HD1 in almost all aspects but with the third person perspective change and with more content/features, not drastically change or redesign things that worked just fine before.

I really wish I could leave a positive review for this game. It still is that game despite several enemy designs trying very hard to counteract this.

Now, the devs do address these issues, but it's rarely ever everything that needs to be. Over time we've had these "it's so over" and "we're so back" tides coming and going for this game. However the devs have in their most recent attempts to please the community, still hidden changes or obfuscated them to make them unclear to players that nerfs every single weapon in the game. Some will say it's in pursuit of difficulty but the deceitfulness towards that goal and the lack of consideration for actually satisfying weapon designs that tightens the game more and more in terms of what loadouts aren't trolling (trolling can be fun though).

I loved this game, a lot. But between performance issues, a weakening meta, awful new enemy designs, poor community communication, and so forth, I just simply have better games to play and learn, so I haven't opened the game for quite some time. I'm not an angry, reactionary reviewer, I'm just sad that the game I enjoyed refuses to excite me with content updates, and instead offers me only more dread at the idea of playing new content.

Do not buy this game. Do not trust a comeback. Do not let news headlines suck you in to giving it a chance. The devs will improve the game, but only to make it even worse in the near future thereafter. I hate it.
